However, they are not obviously bad or \\\\\"video titles\\\\\" and won't stand out to people not that familiar or who don't care.

To sum up: the only disappointment is in the fact that there's plenty of room for all versions of the films, either side by side or through branching, so (aside from the DE of TMP), there's no reason to have left them out. Having all versions would justify the price tag of this double or triple dip. Especially since you know Paramount will release these again with these versions included.

Otherwise, it's a great set. The theatrical cuts are the versions I fell in love with and it's great to have them back. The picture is outstanding, with refreshing sharpness and clarity, while the sound mix is comfortable and satisfying.

5 stars for the presentation
Subtract 2 stars for leaving out the alternate versions.

For fans of the original cuts, this is an essential set. It's up to you to decide if you want to hold out for the next and probably more complete release of these films.bad stuff when I fired up my 52 inch HDTV. You know what I got? An amazing picture - every time. The level of sharpness and clarity to these films is a revelation! I had NEVER seen these films looking so amazingly sharp and detailed. The Wrath of Kahn, which - as noted - got the real restoration, is very nice, but I didn't notice a huge difference between this restoration and the other films. Mostly, I noticed the print was a little darker than prior prints and the other films. The blacks do hold up well on BD, better than on HD-DVD, to my surprise. I have read that those who watch the movies on HUGE screens will notice the DNR, I have to say that my 52 inch, which I sit 6 to 8 feet away from, does not reveal any obvious dullness. And, really, I would assume the great majority of people don't go much larger than 52 inch (unless you have a mansion and more money than God). Honestly, I have no issues with the picture quality, and can wholeheartedly give the picture a thumbs up. The sound is also extremely impressive. The dialog is not lost among the music and sound effects, like so many other HD presentations. The muddiness in much of Kahn and The Search for Spock is not as strong, and the music score for the films never sounded so good. The subtitles for various alien languages are, however, disc generated, not embedded in the films. So the \\\\\"species centric\\\\\" fonts are lost (and, I guess, really doesn't make these true theatrical cuts). However, they are not obviously bad or \\\\\"video titles\\\\\" and won't stand out to people not that familiar or who don't care. To sum up: the only disappointment is in the fact that there's plenty of room for all versions of the films, either side by side or through branching, so (aside from the DE of TMP), there's no reason to have left them out. Having all versions would justify the price tag of this double or triple dip. Especially since you know Paramount will release these again with these versions included. Otherwise,it's a great set. The theatrical cuts are the versions I fell in love with and it's great to have them back. The picture is outstanding, with refreshing sharpness and clarity, while the sound mix is comfortable and satisfying. 5 stars for the presentation Subtract 2 stars for leaving out the alternate versions. For fans of the original cuts, this is an essential set. It's up to you to decide if you want to hold out for the next and probably more complete release of these films."

product_title: Battlestar Galactica
review_headline: A complex and intelligent game for complex and intelligent players
review_body: Battlestar Galactica is the board game that put me firmly in the camp of the \\\\\board game gamer.\\\\\"   When I got this game for myself last Xmas, I was daunted by the long rulebook and the many cards, parts and pieces. It all seemed like too much effort...crisis cards...super crisis cards...Raiders...Heavy Raiders...etcetera. There are many small ships to keep track of and many cardboard pieces which don't always hold up so well after multiple games.   But don't let that stop you. This game is worth the effort.  Since I am a big fan of the \\\\\"Battlestar Galactica\\\\\" TV show, I didn't give up on the game and I played the it at a local gaming convention. And I had a blast!  The Battlestar Galactica board game is complex and time consuming and deals with some adult themes, so I wouldn't recommend it for kids (especially those with short attention spans).  The goal of the game is for the Human fleet to reach the planet Kobol by making FTL (faster than light) \\\\\"jumps\\\\\" through hazardous territory. The Cylons want to prevent this from happening by destroying the Battlestar Galactica or running the Humans out of their four main resources (food, fuel, morale and population) through military attacks and exploiting the mandatory crisis posed to the fleet each turn.  Yes, you'll need at least three hours (give or take) for a game of BSG, but the time spent is worth it, if you ask me.  Yes, making the switch to this kind of complex, adult oriented game isn't easy at first for people who play Parker Brothers board games regularly.  Yes, you will have more fun playing BSG with three or more people. But there are two player and solo rules on the game's web site. I've had fun playing by myself, which (to me) is the sign of a good board game.  Yes, you may get the chance to play as a Cylon and attempt to destroy humanity. Any character being played can be a Cylon, not just the ones who turned out to be such in the TV show. The element of paranoia between the players is a significant element of the game--one which increases with the number of players in the game.  No, everything in the game does not follow the logic set down by the TV show. For example, no character can fly Raptors in the game (Raptors are risked in various card based situations, they don't enter into combat), not even Boomer and Helo who are characters in the TV show who only fly Raptors.  No, it's not easy to be the Humans once a Cylon player is revealed. But that's the point. Human players have to work together to find out which player is a hidden Cylon--while resolving a new crisis every turn, plus Cylon fleet attacks--and then work even harder to fight off the revealed Cylon's determined efforts to destroy humanity.  Yes, each of the main Human (and one Cylon) characters from the first season of the TV show is represented in the game. My favorites are Baltar and Tigh, though Adama and Roslin are great in larger games. And the allure of jumping into a Viper and blasting Cylon Raiders as Apollo or Starbuck is strong.  Yes, Fantasy Flight Games is due to release the Pegasus expansion (in Fall 2009) to the Battlestar Galactica board game, which carries the game through the beginning of season 3 of the TV series.  Whether you like the TV show or hate it, I hope you try and enjoy the Battlestar Galactica board game if what I've written above sounds at all interesting to you."

product_title: Avenger
review_headline: Readers will enjoy the mastery with which Forsyth lays out his thrills. He always delivers. Highly recommended
review_body:
Avenger is a quick read that is intricately plotted with excellent detail and believable action and execution. The characters a well-thought out and believable, and are fleshed out with only the faintest of telling descriptions.

Forsyth's writing technique almost defies summarization, and he divides the narrative into topical chapters that focus on a single thread, the final pattern of the tapestry is not self evident until the final line.

The plot follows the revenge of a wealthy industrialist trying to bring to justice the murder of his beloved grandson. The murderer is a uber-wealthy retired thug in an impregnable fortress in a land beyond justice where he bribed authorities into tame submission. Enter our hero, a lone wolf with just the background to take on the thug.

Readers will enjoy the mastery with which Forsyth lays out his thrills. He always delivers. Highly recommended.

product_title: Use Your Illusion II
review_headline: Roses smell better than guns shoot
review_body: Like its volume 1 counterpart, UYI2 contains enough memorable ballads and a few charming southern rockers to overlook a lengthy majority of dated work which doesn't necessarily stand the test of time.

product_title: Breaking Dawn (The Twilight Saga, Book 4)
review_headline: Excellent plot, no matter what the others say
review_body: I can only imaging how difficult it is to write a final book in a run of bestselling books. Reading the other reviews made me not want to read this book. Everyone kept saying comments like \\\\\jumped the shark.\\\\\" I know that this book tends to reach out to young adults, and maybe many of these people want unresolved drama and death. If that is what you are looking for in an ending, this not the book the read. Meyer is trying to show how through love and cooperation, with her vivid characters, that you can overcome things and have that happy ending. I do not understand why some people would rudely return a book that they had read, or wish for Jacob's death. If that is what you are hoping for, then do not read this book. Meyer ends this on a good note with finality and demonstrating the importance of family. Maybe you would have to experience what it is like to not have a family and then become part of one in order to feel the meaning of this book. She somehow ties up all the loose ends and brings a great ending to this saga. I highly recommend this book, despite the other reviewers. I noticed that the older audience (greater than 20 years old) tends to enjoy this ending more than the younger audience. Maybe there is an understanding that dramatic writing does not need to end with a horrible dramatic finish in order to still have a good ending. Meyer weaves in drama throughout her book to keep you reading, while also bringing a finality to these books. I have read a lot of books before, and people write in their reviews of this book that some of these events are ridiculous. Have you ever thought of vampires and werewolves as ridiculous? These books are fiction. These are not real characters."

product_title: The Script
review_body: Really enjoyed the songs \\\\\The man who can't be moved\\\\\" and \\\\\"breakeven.\\\\\" I almost didn't buy it based on the reviews from this site. One person said it had a lot of foul language. I have listened to the album many times, often not even removing it from the player, and have only found one bad word.     Good sounding band, reminds me a lot of Maroon 5.    Hope this helps..."

product_title: Star Trek (Two-Disc Edition)
review_headline: get a load'a all that shinola they sprayed on that turd!
review_body: first off... I talk too much!:  Before the long wind begins, I will say I did enjoy this film. It did indeed entertain me. The problem always comes with the noisy ruminations of its enthusiastic appreciators.I think that I could get with the prevailing assessment of the \\\\\greatness\\\\\" of this film if there was a modicum of respect for the art that came before it. Like battlestar galactica, like star wars, like the recent installments of superman and batman (the slightly older newer batman - being batman begins actually - coming less than a full decade after the old incarnation) the passionate contemporary blows the loudest horn. The words \\\\\"Younger\\\\\" and \\\\\"better\\\\\", the word \\\\\"sexier\\\\\", the ill gotten word \\\\\"hipper\\\\\" are thrown around as justifications of the product's existence altogether. It's the hip sexiness that makes this new such and such a thousand times better than the old so and so. As if there were any better reason for sprucing up and old car or an old house, than the time honored pursuit of long green! New Money making marketeer barons would have us believe the fairytale that this new re-imagination trend of updating the old was the obligation of the young. It is not, as a matter of fact, to anyone listening, it is not not not! But this is the parlance they use, and no one asks..., yeah but... WHY? Why did it HAVE to happen? It didn't. The suits just thought they could make a buck off something. Yes yes, a built in audience! Excellent marketing savvy there, gentlemen, although if you proceed to change everything in order to make it \\\\\"digest-able\\\\\" to the A.D.D. in you and me, then aren't they effectively alienating those same supposedly built in devotees? Tis indeed a conundrum!     Hubris:  And how does this attitude of better come into the equation. This is such a throw away society that we have television shows that are dedicated to mocking the times and styles of decades past with amusingly clever video blubs and pop up commentary atop stock footage of Wham or the Beatles or President Kennedy and everyone giggles about hair styles and artsy gimmickry. However they're clearly oblivious to the fact that in time the right now will be the back then, and brand new snotties in hipster gear of tomorrow year will be mocking them just as vehemently and thinking themselves just as clever. Comparing the old Battlestar Galactica or Star trek to the new is ridiculously naïve and downright stupid. Of course with the benefit of 20 to 30 years of advancement the look of one thing from now will out shine the lack of gloss of the one thing then. No one looks at photography and says that they're modern Polaroid of their dog, or the digital download of their children in a playground are \\\\\"BETTER\\\\\" than old picture candids of grandma from 1947, it's the substance of the photo, not the quality of the make of the picture. I mean, That argument would be friggin' stupid, wouldn't it?!!! The special effects are a thousand times better, the look is crisper, the visuals stunning. So let that be written down, we all agree. But sorry kids, I can still separate pretty from nourishing. Just a plain pretty look and nothing much in the story department is the equivalent of empty calories. Something to think about.     About the film itself:  For something so new and improved we sure did manage to roll out the Sci Fi cliché machine front and center when we were jotting this three act extravaganza down on paper, didn't we?     MR.BRAIN: Well... first we need a villain, he should be deep and brooding and virtually wordless so we don't have any of those clichéd cartoon mustache twisting villain moments.   MR. PINKY: How can we make him menacing if n' he don't talk, though, boss?  MR.BRAIN: Easy, we'll put sinister looking tattoos all over his face and give him nasty looking serrated edged weapons he can use to slay hapless Starfleet officers!  MR. PINKY: Brilliant, sir! What do we call him?  MR.BRAIN: Darth Maul!  MR. PINKY: Uhh, sir? Seriously?  MR.BRAIN: Yeah you're right, that's been taken. Alright well Roddenberry templated the Romulans against the Romans, roll out the list of roman emperors, drop your finger on a name and let's just move on, ANYTHING BUT CAESAR! That's too obvious.   MR. PINKY: Of course, sir.   MR.BRAIN: Now we don't want Darth Maul...  MR. PINKY: Sir?!  MR.BRAIN: I mean Nero, to be one dimensional, do we? So we'll have to give him purpose, alright, I say page two paragraph six of the vile motivations handbook?  MR. PINKY: Dead wife, sir?  MR.BRAIN: Yes! It worked for Mr. Freeze, didn't it? But lets up the anti_ his whole planet's destroyed and so now he wants to destroy the federation.  MR. PINKY: So the federation destroyed his planet?  MR.BRAIN: Nahh, but we'll come up with some convoluted plot point that'll wrap that all up.  MR. PINKY: How's he try to destroy the federation, sir, Sabotage? Political intrigue?  MR.BRAIN: Are you nuts, that would take whole minutes to establish, and mostly done through dialog! Go to chapter one in the Vile Implementations handbook.  MR. PINKY: Oh sir, you don't mean....?  MR.BRAIN: Yes my friend, the vaunted planet destroying weapon!  MR. PINKY: Didn't we do that with V-Ger in the first film Kahn and the genesis device, or the hunchback whale probe, or with that weirdo nexus ribbon that required the destruction or worlds to be moved, or when that guy who killed Mozart needed a face lift and was willing to use some solar collector thingie on a planet, or that OTHER Romulan dude, Shinzon or whatever, didn't he have a super baddie weapon he planned to use against the federation? And didn't Vader have like two of those types of things?  MR.BRAIN: Your point? It works, don't it?     MR. PINKY: Alright, so we got the federation against a rogue madman with his very own planet destroying weapon and an axe to grind?  MR.BRAIN: Sounds like Gold, don't it?  MR. PINKY: But neither Romulos nor Vulcan were destroyed in Kirks time of star trek, sir, how do we fit this in?  MR.BRAIN: C'mon, use you head willya, Mirror mirror on the wall!  MR. PINKY: Ohh of course sir, an alternate universe! Meaning Nero's a time traveler! The sci Fi trifecta, you are an absolute genius of modern celluloid story crafting, sir.  MR.BRAIN: Yes, yes, you're quite right! Alright my nephew'll be getting home from high school any minute; I get him working on the script as soon as he puts the key in the door!    Get you-self an edu-ma-cation, son:  Sadly I must admit to a prejudice myself, toward these greasy new executive hipsters whom blow in, un-time-tested, with one or two hits under their belt and now suddenly their some prodigy that knows better than everyone. I mean, at first I sort of buy into it cause I saw the flick and didn't vomit so I ran out and snatched up the DVD. Then suddenly you hear it, you hear it right there on the special features. \\\\\"I really wanted to make star trek more like star wars! Fast paced and not so heady.\\\\\" Fair enough, you wanted one classic space opera to be more like another classic space opera more so than you wanted it to be like itself. Alright, knowing you boys the way I do that almost makes some sense. But then they keep talking and you hear things from their own lips like, \\\\\"we took this out because it was too Set-up-ee.\\\\\" And allowing the vocab felony just committed by the word `Set-up-ee', you think; alright, the hipster's panicked that his excuse for dialog is going on too long between explosions. So out comes potentially pertinent information for the sake expediency. (them film jockeys call this \\\\\"pacing\\\\\") You keep moving. Then you get like a twelve and a half minute featurette showing you how the crafty crafters stationed a man just within camera shot so he could shine a flashlight into the lens and give everything a glaring effect. And you go. Well alright, this is sorta like movie magic, I guess, and it...is...worthy of a....full...featurette...........Right? then they talk about the director and the praise his wisdomand how good he is at turning water to wine and making the sick well and the blind see and all that, and then he comes on the scene and claims absolute stupidity, saying he was never a fan of the original trek, he never watched the show, but he had some GREAT IDEAS when they handed the project to him! So now you're like, alright, well.... So the guy's not a fan and... WAIT, WHY THE HELL IS HE MAKING THIS DAMNED MOVIE THEN? And why does an obviously smart man whom makes A-list movies feel compelled to completely downplay his wit in order to put butts in the seats? Has this society become so cynical and paranoid and functionally illiterate that we are dismayed by even the indication of a higher intellect behind our entertainment, or running our COUNTRY?! Are we at a point where a smart man has to play dumb or keep his street credibility and be taken semi seriously on the internet machine? All be told, allowing for Abrams to come out and claim a willful lack of education for himself and also of the genre he's just reinvented, harkens to the new trend of the hapless hero whom is seemingly brilliant by divine intervention and never had to work for his wit or his talents like everyone else. This new Kirk in the movie is a snot nosed kid, subversive and compulsive and reckless, yet someone sees potential in him and urges him to sign up. He even cheats, breaks all the rules and though Spock is a commander while he's still a cadet he is suddenly elevated to captain on his first mission, rising past Spock and a host of others whom I must assume have all been in Starfleet longer and whom presumably did so without faking out the system. I know the original Kirk cheated at the Kobyashi test, but you never get the impression that this was anything more than just an adherence to his own personal ideology that he didn't believe in the no win scenario. The way this is depicted, without any example of otherwise academic achievement on Chris Pines' (his character, not him, I think the dudes a whip ;)) part, we imply that he just got there on the merits of being ballsy and cheating his way through it. Someone should really have a problem with their heroes being depicted this way, but I don't think people were compelled to pay that much attention to the light lunch of characterization they were being spoon fed with sugary visuals! Hmmmmm, wait a minute.... was this Kirk quark a little autobiographical license there by the young upstart in the director's chair? Coincidence? Nahhh!     All put together I began to think to yourself, DID REALLY I JUST FRICKEN SEE AND HEAR WHAT I THOUGHT I SAW AND HEARD? And thus the intellect crusades begin. And there I go off wondering, is it not more important to inspire those still un-jaded and inspirables to CREATING something new?!    Technicality peeves:  Oh and Warp Nacelles are not thrusters, guys. The point is that they WARP space and propel the ship faster than light. They're not Jet afterburners! FYI. There have been literally a zillion tech manuals written on the Trek science, whereas you might think that these details are ridiculous, remember you're making a star trek movie! Don't talk to me about being a geek, you're the head geek in charge now, Mister mister! Can we get a guy that knows a guy to work on getting a guy to work on that? Also, who jettisons a cadet from their ship to a Hoth just because there's a slight disagreement? Doesn't the new flag ship have a brig? Oh, what? Oh, they needed to do that so young Kirk could meet old Spock and Scotty so that act 2 could begin? I see, uhhh.... Alright.... I guess. ;)  BUT I DIGRESS!      Wrap it up!:  My point is for this film and its fans; it could not have been without the original. Mr. Abrams, for all his genuine brilliance, could not have done this without firmly standing on the shoulders of Mr. Roddenberry, without taking from a wealth of pre-established minutia that allowed him the luxury of picking and choosing and then casting the aforementioned\\\\\"New Spin\\\\\". What I fail to understand in this great society of ours is, why does anything new that happens to also be good, have to be good at the expense of what came before? Why does this have to be BETTER? Why would we mock he original actors and what they did and what they left us? I mean, remember acting, folks. True the Shat-inator was over-exuberant from time to time...to time, but there was genuine conveyance of wit and both intellect and emotion from these highly capable people. We're mocking that against modern characteristic development? Are you serious? I think it would be easier to agree that it was a fast paced, enjoyable film that allowed new perspectives and new directions to be taken with old favorites if there wasn't automatically this seeming inescapable negative slant against the old for the exaltation of the new. The new is pretty, the new is newer, stylized and kinetically meeting the manic short attention span standards of the eyes of today. It has not been proven, it has not been weighed or time tested at the moment, it should be given a chance, but exaltation waits until exaltation is earned. As we have clearly learned with the original trek movies, and the new star wars, and even the new dune novels, NOTHING IS AN ABSOLUTE WIN.     I liked the film, I liked it a lot. I want more of this, but I want substance with it too, and I am harsh because I can see the trend trending away from weight and further and further towards fluff, toward \\\\\"easy\\\\\". Visuals are easy. I can think of a visual: a giant octopus wrapped tight around the empire state building, swatting battle ships out of the river while whistling the star spangled banner!: doesn't make that visual compelling or intriguing, (well kinda...) it's just a visual! It's not the film; it's the new ideological hubris I feel it represents.         And.....................breath..."

product_title: The Lovely Bones
review_headline: I've come to Amazon for spoilers - so I don't have to finish this tedious book
review_body: Yes, it started well. The type of book you allow yourself to keep reading despite the average writing style because the story is a 'page-turner'. Then the story, before any conclusions, reaches a cliff and drops down it...... I've come to Amazon to get a two paragraph summary of the end of the story, as I will not be finishing the book. Not recommended.

product_title: The Phantom of the Opera (Widescreen Edition)
review_headline: As good as you can get without being there live
review_body: I have seen The Phantom of the Opera live in NYC and this movie is as close as you can get to being there live.  Of course, Gerard Butler is no Michael Crawford but the scenery is gorgeous and the singing is fabulous so it's no great loss.  It was a great way to introduce my children to something from Broadway without spending the money to go.

product_title: Fall of Giants (The Century Trilogy, Book One)
review_body: \\\\\Fall of Giants\\\\\" isn't an epic novel like \\\\\"Pillars of the Earth\\\\\" or \\\\\"World Without End\\\\\". It covers a relatively short time period (1911 - 1924) which allowed the author to go deeper with the characters of the novel. I enjoyed and recommend the book. Far above most books on Best Sellers lists."

product_title: Ip Man
review_headline: Great Martial Arts Film for the Intellect
review_body: whats great about this film is that it wasn't the typical martial arts films with fighters ridiculously flying through the air with cgi effects spraying blood all over the place. this is a film a martial artist can appreaciate with a accurate and skilled display of this particular form of kung fu \\\\\Wing Chun\\\\\". the cinematography was beautifuly shot and action scenes were rich with good fighting displays  the story revolve's around the history of bruce lee's teacher known as IP Man, what i also liked about the plot is that it touched on the decadence of pre war china, and the degrading humiliation many of these great martial arts teachers had to endure after the japanese invasion.very enlightening film it made me want to do more research on the subject after viewing.  if you appreciate films like hero, curse of the golden flower, martial arts films with a complex plot then you'll appreciate this. definatly one that stands out in the genre"

product_title: C Programming Language, 2nd Edition
review_headline: Definitely not a tutorial, but a detailed definition of The Language
review_body: Whether of not this book will work for you will depend on your background and what you want from it. As the Preface to the First Edition says: \\\\\... C was originally designed for and implemented on the UNIX operating system on the DEC-PDP-11 by Dennis Ritchie\\\\\". But that's not the only reason that the book is considered \\\\\"the classic\\\\\" treatment of the C language. How often do you get a definitive treatment of a language by the folks who designed it? (And yes, I am aware of the Stroustrup/C++ connection). I had a well-used copy of the original edition on my bookshelf for years.    But, while it may be definitive, it is not the best reference or language tutorial for non-programmers, or maybe even for programmers coming from other languages, who want to learn C.  For that, try Stephan Kochan's \\\\\"Programming in C\\\\\". And Sam Harbison's \\\\\"C, A Reference Manual\\\\\" is where I start looking for nit-picky points of using the language."

product_title: G N' R Lies
review_headline: Just some exclusive bonuses that never appeared on Appetite For Destruction....
review_body: Like I said in title, if Appetite For Destruction would add a bonus CD, adding songs that were possible to be on Appetite For Destruction, these songs would be on that CD. Even though I said \\\\\Just some....\\\\\" doesn't mean it is not good, actually, I find it's better than the Use Your Illusion Albums. Just for your information, Rose stated that he didn't like how he sounded on the album because his voice sounded rough around the edges (for example, the album has the song \\\\\"Move to the City\\\\\" which Rose's voice sounds like on \\\\\"You Could Be Mine\\\\\" from Use Your Illusion II).        The first half of the album (The A-Side of the album if using cassette tape or Vinyl) is live, while the other half (or B-Side) is acoustic. The first track on the album is a song called \\\\\"Reckless Life\\\\\" which believe it or not, was the first song written by the band, being written around 1979-1981. The song starts out with an explicit shout out, but the rest of the song is not explicit. The second track is \\\\\"Nice Boys\\\\\", a cover that was originally by Rose Tattoo. The third track is \\\\\"Move to the City\\\\\", with Rose saying an explicit line a few times. The fourth track is \\\\\"Mama Kin\\\\\" a song originally by Aerosmith. The fifth track is an acoustic love song, called \\\\\"Patience\\\\\". It has some of the most beautiful lyrics I ever heard. The sixth track is a song called \\\\\"Used To Love Her\\\\\". The song is a joke about Rose's dog (stating, \\\\\"I used to Love her, but I had to kill her. I knew I'd miss her, now she's buried right in my backyard). The seventh track \\\\\"You're Crazy\\\\\" (originally known from Appetite For Destruction in it's faster form) is acoustic, even though it was performed with electric guitars on Appetite For Destruction, it was originally attended to be an acoustic song, like it is on here. The eighth and last track on the album is \\\\\"One in a Million\\\\\", a one of many songs that shows how talented Axl Rose is at writing songs. It is a very beautiful song and a very offensive song at the same time. My favorite thing about this song is that, at the end, Rose states how he is not perfect, and telling people they should accept themselves for who they are, that everyone is perfect in their own way (the lyrics, \\\\\"You're One in a Million, that's what you are. You're One in a Million babe, you're a shooting star. Maybe someday we'll see you, before you make us cry. You know we tried to reach you, but you were much too high.\\\\\" and \\\\\"Some say I'm lazy, some say that's just me. Some may think I'm crazy, I guess I'll always be\\\\\"). A great album, and I recommend for you to buy it."

product_title: Plate to Pixel: Digital Food Photography & Styling
review_body: I have just received a copy of \\\\\Plate to Pixel\\\\\" yesterday and I am really thrilled! I could not put this book down (my family can testify as dinner came later than usual...).    I am amazed at how much extensive information the book provides and how clearly the information is organized throughout the book including many examples in real life situations, great pictures and illustrations, settings, tips...     The style all along is very easy to grasp and convivial. You almost feel as if the author is sitting on a chair next to you sharing a cup of coffee while explaining in detail the ins and outs. It just flows naturally and you learn so much out of it.    I would definitely highly recommend this book! The book offers a tremendous amount of useful information on both photography itself and food styling. Obviously, all pictures are amazing as you can expect for those of you already familiar with Tartelette's blog. The resource list at the end of the book is also a very nice added bonus!     I am grateful to the author for doing such hard work with such ease!"

product_title: Room
review_body:
Five year old Jack doesn't know anything of the world but Room. He was born in the eleven by eleven foot space and has never set foot outside of it. His Ma was kidnapped by Old Nick seven years ago and has been held captive in Room ever since. Ma has worked hard to make sure that Jack doesn't suspect that Room is a prison but she doesn't know how much longer she can take being held hostage.

This book was wonderful for so many reasons. I will admit when my book club chose it for one of our monthly selections, I was not looking forward to reading it. Since having kids of my own, I don't have much of a stomach for reading books in which bad things happen to children. Room pleasantly surprised me - as far as Jack is concerned being in Room is not all that bad. Because it's all he's ever known and Ma has carefully sheltered him from knowledge of the outside world, he's actually a pretty happy child. There are definitely some parts of the book that are tough to read but it wasn't as wrenching as I thought it would be.

I really appreciated the attention to detail the author had when writing this book. She actually had her brother-in-law design a scale CAD design of Room and all its furnishings so that she could get an accurate feel for what living in an eleven by eleven room would be like. You can find this design on her website. She did a great job of realizing the many aspects of Jack's development that would be affected by growing up in Room - physical, emotional and intellectual. He was affected in ways I never would have considered myself but that made total sense.

I had the pleasure of hearing Ms. Donoghue speak at an event put on by my local independent bookstore, Rainy Day Books. I can't really get into what she talked about too much because it would spoil the story but it definitely added to my enjoyment of the book to know why she made the choices she did with the direction the plot went and with the way characters were portrayed.

This book led to one of the most robust book club discussions my club has had. The story was so intriguing and thought-provoking; there were all kinds of issues to talk about. I highly recommend this book.of the most robust book club discussions my club has had. The story was so intriguing and thought-provoking; there were all kinds of issues to talk about. I highly recommend this book.

product_title: A Song of Ice and Fire, (4 Vols.): A Game of Thrones / A Clash of Kings / A Storm of Swords / A Feast for Crows
review_body: I was enchanted by the HBO series and wanted to read the whole thing. But maybe I should not have bought the four book set.  I have to say (along with everyone else) that I loved the first three books. I couldn't put them down.  By Book 4 (A Feast for Crows) however, I began to feel like I'd fallen for a \\\\\bait and switch\\\\\" scam.   Too many cliff hangers, too little character development. And my favorite character, Tyrion, is neglected. I finally started skipping some chapters entirely. How many times do I want to hear the same things again and again? I got tired of the endless back story that was inserted--all too regularly--into nearly every chapter. It's as though GRRM wanted to make each book accessible on its own to a new reader who hadn't read the previous books.  This makes book 4 no fun at all.  Not to mention all the subplots and side stories that distract from the major developments.  It's ok to ask the reader to suspend judgment from time to time, but enough is enough.     GRRM needs to put us all out of our misery and finish this series.  I'm not even going to bother with Book 5 and will wait and see if HBO does a better job of doing the project more quickly and succinctly--before all the actors get too old and die.      Read Books 1-3 and enjoy them, but don't expect the satisfaction to continue or the story to be done.     Maybe I'll read the final book when it comes out, but as a reader I feel that the author has broken his pact with the audience--to (as others have said) \\\\\"move the story along.\\\\\"    Too bad."

product_title: Breaking Dawn (The Twilight Saga, Book 4)
review_body: I read the previous reviews regarding Breaking Dawn after I ordered the book (I am a twi-hard after all) and I immediately panicked.  Would the book forever destroy my love of Twilight?  I should confess right here and now that this is the first of her books I have actually read, being introduced to the saga through the films.   Already 2/3rds through Breaking Dawn and relieved to say that although I appreciate the previous reviewers grievances, - I am still fully caught up in the story and just as engrossed as I have been in the previous 3 films.  Perhaps being able to so clearly visualize my favorite characters has assisted with this?  .....as previously stated, not having read her previous books (although having read the Amazon reviews of Breaking Dawn, I am curious to see if they are any better) I can confidently state that Breaking Dawn is no literary feat....just a jolly good yarn.  There is no doubt Stephanie Meyer can tell a tale.  Very like reading the conscious stream of a tall-tale-telling teenager who is desperate to be transported in romantic love and and generally admired and adored by the whole world, and of-course... hormonally overstimulated ...nothing really ground breaking there.  So regardless, if like me, you were 'turned' by the films and just can't wait till the next two cinema installments to find out what happens to Bella Edward Jake and the gang, then go ahead. Just make sure you have the cinema versions bevy of beautiful faces in your head - it will help ease the gaps and smooth the bumps - no pun intended.   Oh- and naturally don't forget to suspend all disbelief (and be forgiving of the narrative - particularly the descriptive) as you go, after all isn't that the first commandment of a book of this genre?

product_title: Arctic Silver 5 Polysynthetic Silver Thermal Compound Paste 3.5g
review_body:
I have used better over the years so I was extremely surprised by all the recommendations toward this product.

1) What I received in the mail was a single vial of thermal grease, in a syringe. No instructions, no packaging. So maybe that was a seller issue but to recive 0 documentation with it was a surprise.

2) On their website, the instructions are very specific on how to apply depending on your cpu. However, for ridged or non-flat heatsinks, the painfully (no joke, over 12 pages) instructions become plain dumb (involving a credit card, razor and coffee filter). Look, I get where they were going but they don't have a sperate pdf for non-flat heatsinks if the new instructions boil down to \\\\\fill the gaps\\\\\".

Hopefully the actual product will be stellar over the long run but the everything including the installation has left a lot to be desired."

product_title: The Goonies
review_body: This movie is a classic. Fun for all ages. I have been watching this movie for over 20 years, and still love it. The Goonies is the story of a group of young teens in the search for a legendary hidden treasure, in order to save their town from being turned into a golf course. They have a map, bad guys chasing them all the way, fun and adventure.

product_title: Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close (DVD)
review_body: Considering it was based on the novel of the same name by Jonathan Safran Foer, the young writer whose success has polarized a portion of the literary community, it's not surprising that Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close has had nearly the same effect on most people. The only film nominated for this year's Best Picture Oscar that I would give 1 star, Extremely Loud stars former Kids Jeopardy! winner-turned-actor Thomas Horn as Oskar Schell, son of a 9/11 victim, who must learn to cope with life in the wake of his father's death. A year after the tragedy, when Oskar discovers a mysterious key among his father's belongings, he sets out to discover what it unlocks. Extremely Loud is a worthy story to tell, but director Stephen Daldry tells it in such a pretentious and shamelessly sentimental fashion as to make it distasteful.

product_title: Fifty Shades of Grey: Book One of the Fifty Shades Trilogy (Fifty Shades of Grey Series)
review_headline: I've read better erotica!!! The hype over this book is dumb!!!
review_body:
I love erotica books so when I found out this was one, I decided to read it. And the hype surrounding it had me wondering. I love being \\\\\in the know.\\\\\"

Anyway, this book is very boring and repetitive, like everyone says. The same phrases over and over. Characters are weird and somehow interwined in each others lives. The sex scenes were cool at first but after while got long and boring and just had me saying \\\\\"ummmm.\\\\\" And Anastacia climaxes so easy. I mean come on now; we all wish right?

I wouldn't recommend this book to any other erotica readers. I finished the book although I wanted to stop at the half point. Didn't want to feel like a loser so I finished; the only reason. I don't know who this author is but she definitely probably paid for the publicity; someway, somehow. Ain't hating but she got her money with a bad read.

If you like erotica, read Zane books. She definitely deserves recognition and the scenes are amazing!"

product_title: Fifty Shades Darker
review_body: I bought the trilogy.  They were a forth grader level of reading so I finished them all in one day.  I didn't buy them for their intellectual content so I could get past the poor writing, but what I was surprised with is how boring, tame, and childish they were.  I was looking for something new, exciting, something, perhaps, that I had missed out on given my generation (hippy era, free love and all that)...sheez I'm telling you, women these days must be awfully frustrated, naive or infantile if this read turned them on.  I guess we still haven't gotten past the pat on the behind started at birth, this and a pair of handcuffs is all you're going to find in this book.  Save your money...find a cop and ask for a spanking!

product_title: Structures: Or Why Things Don't Fall Down
review_body: ...By God and Man, is reviewed along the way by Gordon. While Timoshenko authors on the History of the Strength of Materials but really reviews the history of elasticity theory (Gordon lists him in the references at the end in Structures, as well as Cottrell- both outstanding men in their fields) Gordon ENLIGHTENS as to why things are the way they are and for better or worse were made that way. Not math intensive- you'll have to see Timoshenko for that. On the other hand, Timoshenko hardly touches on why materials crack and break, whereas Gordon reveals all on that topic. A Must Read for Engineers- Structural, Mechanical, Metallurgical, Materials-

product_title: Fifty Shades of Grey: Book One of the Fifty Shades Trilogy (Fifty Shades of Grey Series)
review_headline: It was good for a first effort
review_body: I purchased this book a few weeks ago for a girls weekend where we would be discussing the book.  Everyone else had read it but me, so I decided I should get it so I could participate in the discussion.  I thought it was a decent book, but I could tell it was the first book she had ever written.  From her descriptions of certain things in the book, it appears that she had definitely done some active research.  This isn't really my genre of book, but it was interesting.  I like reading books that I can't put down, this was not one of them.  I could stop at the end of any chapter & not necessarily be compelled to read the next chapter.  I'm currently debating on whether or not to finish the trilogy.  My friends say that books 2 & 3 give explanations, more character studies & are much better in general than the first book.  So maybe I will, but I'm not in a hurry.

product_title: Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail
review_body:
Following her mother's death, the break up of her marriage, and some clear indications that her life was falling apart, Cheryl Strayed made the decision at the age of twenty six to hike the Pacific Crest Trail alone in an effort to find herself again. While outdoorsy, Cheryl lacked any previous experience backpacking and quickly found out that the trail would challenge her more than she ever thought possible. She also finds out that the trail will bring rewards both mentally and physically that would far outweigh the hardships.

I wish I could give ten stars to this book. It is a brave memoir, as Cheryl holds nothing back, including shameful experiences with drugs, heartbreaking final moments with her mother, and feelings of inadequacy compared to the more prepared and experienced hikers she encounters. It is truthful in that sometimes she feels like giving up, or wondering what the whole point of the experience is at her low moments. She also experiences magical moments that she wouldn't have with a large group such as coming across a beautiful red fox on the trail or feeling simultaneously vulnerable and secure alone in her tent at night. The glimpses she shares of her life pre Pacific Crest Trail are carefully chosen, and I feel like every story she shared had some meaning to the path of her life and the woman she became. Highly recommended for women, outdoor enthusiasts, or anyone who needs some inspiration in their own life.

product_title: Paranormal Activity 4 - Rated
review_body:
The Paranormal Activity film series continues with this fourth entry. This time, the cell phones and computer cameras are focused on a teenage girl (Kathryn Newton) whose family allow a young boy in their neighborhood named Robbie (Brady Allen) to stay with them while his mom is sick. Soon after, eerie things start happening in the household, some of which focus on the girl's younger brother Wyatt. As the bumps in the night become more pronounced, the mysteries surrounding Robbie's family and the house across the street grow to the point where the only thing for the teen girl to do is investigate herself.

I really enjoyed PA 1 and 2, 3 was okay and I was really disappointed with this one. It leaves more questions than answers and the ending happens so fast, you're wondering did that really happen?? As with the other movies, the beginning is slow and the tension slowly, slowly builds. If there is a part 5, I hope it answers the questions brought by part 4. What was the connection with Wyatt? If Robbie was \\\\\Hunter\\\\\"? Why were they after Wyatt? I think they are starting to run out of ideas and if that's case, maybe it's time to retire the PA series.

Unless you are a diehard fan, wait for this one to come on cable, don't waste your money!!!"

product_title: Hooker 'N Heat
review_body: This a great blues album. \\\\\Hooker N Heat\\\\\" is a double disc collection, the first disc is John Lee Hooker accompanying himself on electric guitar. On the second disc he is tastefully accompanied by the west coast blues rock band Canned Heat. On so many of Hookers early studio recordings \\\\\"The Boogie Man\\\\\" was forced to work with studio musicians who didn't recognize the genius of his groove based, somewhat unpredictable, and idiosyncratic style. Often you would hear the band play chord changes that they thought should be there rather than following what John Lee was actually playing. This match up, with a popular white blues rock band of the time, may have begun as marketing ploy but turned out to be a match made in blues heaven. The talented young musicians in Canned Heat, accomplished bluesmen in their own right, obviously respected John Lee Hooker and recognized the value of his unique style. Likewise Hooker seems to genuinely enjoy playing with these young bluesmen, especially the late great harp man Alan \\\\\"Blind Owl\\\\\" Wilson. This album captures the essence of what happened when two generations of American blues musicians got together for a jam in 1970."

product_title: The 2nd Law [Explicit]

Electronic and Pop/Dance sounds fill a good percentage of the album, but some moodier gems can be found throughout.  The radio friendly "Madness" is incredible!  That alone is proof that the band is reaching out in many different directions.  It is not, as some Muse fans stipulate, a "sellout" for dollars.  The song is just downright groovy and has a perfect beat and rise and fall crescendo that can't help but put you in a good mood.

product_title: The Night Circus
review_body:
I was given a brief synopsis of the book before I read it. I was expecting magic. There were two different types of magic in this book: the content and the style. The content made \\\\\magic\\\\\" an accessible reality. It seemed perfectly reasonable that there is a way the world works that only a few people can see and consequently manipulate. The magic of the writing is that it made everything exceedingly tangible. I've never read anything like it. There is a flavor in the words on the page; the abrupt introduction of the present tense at pivotal moments makes the events of the story abruptly and delightfully real. I regretted getting the book on Kindle: it felt like a novel that needed to be held in one's hands.

The story is thought-provoking, the atmosphere is captivating, and the course of the novel develops into maturity along with its characters. It has the distinct feeling throughout of puzzle pieces slowly falling into place, especially since the story is told out of a strictly chronological order.

I would recommend this book to anyone who wishes to escape to a world where dreams are real."

product_title: An Abundance of Katherines
review_body: I'm a bit disappointed by this book after reading The Fault in Our Stars and Paper Towns. Compared to those two, this one just seems to be missing something. It wasn't quite as funny as those two either. It has an interesting premise, but I did not connect with the character Collin. He is obsessed with anagrams and trying to find a theorem that can predict how future relationships will end. I find both of those things to be very interesting, but there can only be a certain amount of ranting about theorems because I stop caring. The book definitely has some twists and turns that keep me interested. However, none of those points made me think \\\\\Gee, this is my new favorite book\\\\\"."

What we all deeply appreciate is that acorns can be earned and won without money. It is so frustrating to play games where you can not get the really cool things unless you pay money. product_title: Project X (Extended Cut) [Blu-ray]
review_headline: TO SOME THIS IS ENTERTAINMENT, BUT NOT FOR ME!
review_body:
Man did I feel old watching this train wreck of a film. A completely senseless barrage of quick cuts, boobs and stupidly. We've all been there before. Parents are out of town, time to call the crew and PARTY!! Right? I'm no exception to that one, but there is something seriously wrong with our society and the younger generation today. Completely amoral, without any self worth or character. The only thing these morons respect is money no matter how it is acquired. What's scarier is one of these A Holes will be running this country some day...hopefully I'll be long gone by then!

I know, I know its only a movie, but it's a far too real reflection of our society for it to be funny to me, it's just sad and depressing. I give it two stars because I watched it all the way through and it was good enough for me to actually write about it.

product_title: Kveikur
review_body:
This is slightly different to what I was expecting. I can go days and play nothing but Sigur Ros, so I am well defined as a big fan.
Mostly, I favor the achingly beautiful, almost dirge like songs (Andvari, Refur, Von, All Alright, Glosoli, Festival), but this CD surprised me.
It does have more of an edge, perhaps a bit more "bite" than most of their recent work.
Nevertheless, it only took me one listen to want to go back and play all the songs again.
Of course I would listen to this band if they put Wikipedia pages to music, so I may not be the most reliable source.
To me, Sigur Ros is a conduit to something much bigger than themselves.
I often feel their music was there when the Universe was created.
All fans: Buy this CD. New fans: explore the catalog. This is greatness.

product_title: Days Are Gone
review_body:
Yes that's what I said...you may ask, who is Fanny?? Well, Fanny were the first all-female rock & roll band signed to a major label (Warner/Reprise) back in the late 60s. Hearing Haim's long-in-the-works debut album, \\\\\Days Are Gone\\\\\", I was grinning from ear-to-ear!! Vocally, the Haim sisters reminded me a LOT of the Millington sisters of Fanny...but without sounding retro in the least. They have 80s and R&B influences galore, but not a pastiche. If anything, and this is exciting, it's like the Haim sisters took synthetic 80s pop music and translated it to be played organically, as if they were in the 70s So-Cal Laurel Canyon scene.

The tunes are catchy-as-hell but not formulaic...they sure know what they are doing. I am not surprised the UK took to em first...they don't sound American really...they sound like Brits or Swedes IMITATING 70s So-Cal female American bands but with an 80s Euro approach...

The songs are fresh, enticing, and exciting...now I want the 2CD import on Polydor/Universal UK with 2 B-sides, a live track and a slew of remixes!!

Fave new band by far!!"

product_title: Allegiant (Divergent Trilogy, Book 3)
review_body:
Many people have decried about the ending, but that’s not even half of what makes this book a total and complete fail.
Early on, when they announced Allegiant would be written from both Tris and Tobias’s point of views (POVs) I was cautiously excited. I really looked forward to getting to know Tobias better (by seeing things through his mind’s filter). And then I read it…utterly disappointing.

Did an editor even look at this manuscript before it went to press? Tris and Tobias think and process the SAME exact way. This is nothing short of poor and amateur writing abilities on display. Doing the two POV’s exposed Roth’s weaknesses as a writer—she could only write one character moderately well. All others were cardboard. No two people think and process the same on earth. A good writer makes it so that the POV ‘voices’ are so different that a reader can open a book to any page, remove name references, and STILL know who’s head we’re in. Roth failed to do this and this is the ultimate failing of the book.

Okay…and for her next book, can someone please help her brainstorm so every plot twist isn’t either solved or thicken by the introduction of a new serum. Seriously. It was like: Ahhh…the world is ending! I know. Oh let’s say there’s ANOTHER serum that gives people longer life and ANOTHER serum that heals wounds and ANOTHER serum that makes mean people smile and ANOTHER serum that tames unicorns and ANOTHER serum that…you get my point.

Also, can someone please give the author some romance lessons? I mean…I guess romance in her eyes is “let’s fight and be mad and OH! let’s make out for a chapter, but now I’m mad again, but let’s find some place to make-out.” If that’s considered good romantic tension these days it’s no wonder the divorce rates are rising. But really, again, it just exposed shoddy writing. Roth can’t figure out how to create genuine romantic tension for her characters. Period.

And the ending. Yes. We can’t ignore that (unfortunately, because I’d sure like to). Honestly, Roth’s characterization was so weak in this third book (because of the POV failure) that I didn’t even care by the time I got to the last couple chapters. That being said—I’m not entirely opposed to killing off characters (I’ve done so in my own books), but how Roth did it was wrong and ruined the entire series.

Allegiant and subsequently its author, Veronica Roth (who, for the rest of this will be known as VRoth) failed readers on so many levels, but more than anything it/she failed a generation of teen readers who are looking for a new brand of hope.

See, when an author writes a book they can’t just willy-nilly send it out into the world. They must keep in mind that their words have the power to shape and affect people. An author, especially someone with a huge readership, has a responsibility to their readers. They must offer hope within the pages of their book or it’s a pointless waste of time for the author and more so, the reader.

Author William Faulkner said in his acceptance speech for his Nobel Prize, “The writer’s duty is to help man endure by lifting his heart, by reminding him of the courage and honor and hope and pride and compassion and pity and sacrifice which have been the glory of his past.”

Does there have to be an “and they lived happily ever after” ending? Absolutely not. Suzanne Collins’s (author of The Hunger Games series) editor put it best when she said that young adult books don’t need a happy ending, but in the end, there must be “a window left open”—a way where we can see that the characters we’ve grown to love can move on from tragedy.
There must be hope.

Teens today are growing up in a far different world than the one I grew up in (and I’m not that old). I’m of the Harry Potter generation. The books of my youth were stories of teens that could rise up and save the world. My generation was the one told that if we go to college and work hard then we’ll get good jobs and we can accomplish anything. I’m the generation just in front of today’s teens—and the teens of today have watched as the bottom dropped out of my generation’s lives. Where going to college hasn’t landed many of my friends a job, instead it has left them drowning in debt. Where many parents are divorced and a significant amount of people I know have watched their family home seized by forecloser.

Teens today have grown up watching this all unravel. For all of the aware part of their lives, our country has been at war. Think about that. They don’t know of an America not at war. Polls show that their vision of success is very different than my teen generation (which is only ten years ago). Today’s teen sees success not as owning a home, graduating college, having a family, or starting a business, instead the number one measure of success in recent polls showed them wanting to be debt free “at some point in life.” That’s it.

Contemporary teens aren’t looking for books about teens saving the world. They only ask for the small hope of saving their small corner of it. So popular books for this generation are ones that in the end show that in the midst of a messed up world, you can find your own peace/hope, even if it’s just between you and one other person.

Fiction has always been meant to combat the reality of life. VRoth failed us here. She didn’t show us what could be possible. Instead she smacked us in the face with what is. And we don’t need that. Because we’ve all dealt with more than enough loss and hardship and heartbreak. We don’t need books that repeat what we live every single day, we need books that show us that in the midst of a heartbreak world, we can find our own little pod of happiness/joy. That just because the world we live in is going to pot, doesn’t mean we have to lose hope.

Whatever her purpose, VRoth showed teens with Allegiant one horrible thing: their life, their struggles, their fight for right…none of it matters in the end. Which leaves teens asking: what’s the point? If nothing I’m working for matters…why try? I know that’s not the message she meant to send, but when an author is careless with their responsibility to readers, this is the kind of thing that can happen.

I’ll admit I spent a good amount of time reading Amazon reviews for Allegiant in order to see if I was the only one left disillusioned. I wasn’t. Sadly, I’m in the majority with the one star reviews.

Most of the five star reviews I read were people who applauded VRoth on her bravery in “giving a realistic ending.” To this I say: there is a whole genre dedicated to realism. If you want stories that make you feel like someone has stabbed your heart on the last page with no chance for recovery, then feel free to read that genre. But for the ninety-five percent of people that read for enjoyment and escapism, sorry, we want some glimmer of a happy ending. If the Divergent series was meant to belong in the realism genre then it was marketed terribly because right now, all we have are broken promises to readers.
Also, even within realism, hope is usually the end game.

Take the book The Fault in Our Stars which falls in the realism genre, the teens in the story who fall in love both have terminal cancer. In the end of the book Augustus dies. Why weren’t readers rioting over that? Because a promise wasn’t broken—when they picked up the book they knew they were going to read a story about dying teens so a teen dying at the end of the book was something they were braced for, if not expecting.

Even still, The Fault in Our Stars ends with hope. Hazel realizes that although Augustus has died, her love for him doesn’t have to. Death doesn’t have to change the definition of relationships. My grandfather, who is deceased, is still my grandfather because I’m living and can claim him as such. The last line of the book is in present tense whereas the rest of the book was in past tense. Meaning life goes on. This is a hopeful message.

VRoth killed her main character which is just hard to do well, especially in young adult fiction. Unless the author brings the character back after death (like Harry Potter), a theme/point is better demonstrated through killing a beloved secondary character like Augustus in The Fault in Our Stars or Piggy in Lord of the Flies (how’s that for old school). Otherwise, just save it for realism or adult fiction. Period.pot, doesn’t mean we have to lose hope.

Whatever her purpose, VRoth showed teens with Allegiant one horrible thing: their life, their struggles, their fight for right…none of it matters in the end. Which leaves teens asking: what’s the point? If nothing I’m working for matters…why try? I know that’s not the message she meant to send, but when an author is careless with their responsibility to readers, this is the kind of thing that can happen.

But for the ninety-five percent of people that read for enjoyment and escapism, sorry, we want some glimmer of a happy ending. product_title: Fifty Shades Freed (Fifty Shades, Book 3)
review_body: I heard a lot of positive reviews about this book ( all 3 of them), so I had to get it. It turns out, if you take all that sex out, you could fit all 3 books in less then 50 pages. Christian is immature, acting like 17 year old boy, Ana's excuse for everything is - he is broken, " Oh, my poor Fifty" . It seems all they do is have sex, every couple of minutes, it's a miracle they can get anything done.  I think they should both see a psychiatrist for 2nd opinion, since I do not think Dr. F. is doing good job now. Also, one thing that I  could just  not get over and it was driving me crazy was - Ana and her inner "goddess" and her subconscious with her half moon glasses, just annoying. Ana has to ask for permission to do anything- go to work, visit friends, got out with friends, while it's ok for Christian to see/ talk to  Mrs. Johnson and his other subs. And I had to wait for book # 3 to hear what " but plugs" are, and it turns out it's not that exciting. In all honesty, I do understand why most people think this book is awesome- all that sex ( unhealthy relationship, but full of sex) can be interesting to some, but if you are looking for something that has a real story, just find another book.

product_title: The Goldfinch: A Novel (Pulitzer Prize for Fiction)
review_headline: Kept me interested enough to read the end but nothing else.
review_body:
This book feels, like others have suggested, that you are reading little novellas, as you go through the big changes that happen in Theo Decker's life. The first part was the most interesting to me, when he and his mother experience tragedy in the museum and what happens to Theo afterwards.

His time in Vegas was just an awful slog to read through. I felt dark and unhappy through it all as the author went into verbose descriptions of drug abuse and the highs and lows that followed, and Theo's time there was so lonely and neglectful.

I get how the story all came together at the end, when there was a little bit more action as the characters strove to recover Theo's most valued possession, and I'm glad she wrapped it up nicely, but it was so long-winded. The author is an incredible writer with brilliant metaphors and descriptions, but I skimmed more through this book than I ever do. I usually hate to miss anything but I had to just to get through it, especially the very end.

Also, there is a lot of vulgar language and swearing that I got tired of reading over and over again.

He forms an attachment to a digital character, and although it was sort of interesting...it just never felt real enough for me to believe this human actor was bonding with the digital character. He ends up battling a small band of bounty hunters, and nothing he does was Riddick like...so, I felt a bit confused and disappointed at the end of the movie. Where was my Riddick?  :)

product_title: A Game of Thrones (A Song of Ice and Fire, Book 1)
review_body: There's an edgy authority to GRR Martin's books that I really enjoy. And then there's a voice. It reminded me of the northern story-tellers that kept you riveted hour after hour, the ones that acted out their tales by the light of a campfire. Powerful, fantasy-packed fun all the way through and larger-than-life characters you love to hate. The only stumbling block for me was the profanity and some very explicit scenes. But roll-on GRRM and give us a few more. The movie-makers are catching up!

product_title: Heaven's Gate (Criterion Collection) [Blu-ray]
review_headline: Not the Greatest Western Ever Made, but Quite Far From the Worst
review_body:
Thank goodness for the Criterion Collection Blu-ray restoration of the full 216 minute film that originally premiered in NYC. Technically it brings the video and audio quality up to where it should be for home Blu-ray release. In general, it allows one to fully appreciate the outstanding cinematography, sweeping vista scenes (reminiscent of some of Davd Lean's work) and sound work.

The film was skewered by critics when originally released in 1980, at least some of which was a dog pile precipitated by the industry press coverage about the film's massive overruns in shooting schedule and budget. Even today, too many critics slam films that have production problems because of them and not the final result (The Lone Ranger is an example). United Artists didn't help by pulling it immediately after the NYC premier and having the 216 minute run-time hacked down to 149 minutes for wider release. That left the film with holes; it didn't tell enough of the story. The full 216 minute version isn't perfect, but it's much more cohesive. There are sections that could be a few seconds shorter to pick up the pace slightly. This is mostly near the beginning that sets an environment for the story, but not by much -- a few minutes total cut -- certainly nowhere near an hour. Perhaps among the biggest problems critics had with Heaven's Gate is that it's not a high concept film. They either wanted it to be one or were expecting it to be one, and when it wasn't they dished out their punishment.

Approach the film without preconceptions from reviews you might have read or what a western genre film should or should not be. Keep your mind open and look beyond its genre into the narrative and its underlying themes. There is where I believe you'll find the power of the film and the story it tells about wealth, power, privilege and class warfare in the late 19th Century west.

product_title: Mini Piano ®
review_body: My wife, Gloria found the Mini Piano app, and she loves it!  She says that the notes sound good. She plays by ear.

Were I to judge this cd on technique, it would get five stars. However, technique is practice...training...and though I would never derogate it (that would be perilously close to criticizing Bird for technique and that would be borderline insane), it no longer thrills the same way rich composition does. It is probably true that there are many years ahead of new compositions, but I am afraid that it is much more difficult to find interesting intervals and arresting harmonies. Metheny, from around 1978 to 1993, filled the universe with compositions and arrangements that were as tuneful as they were technical. He was not alone in that universe--Brazilians, at that time, were good company--Tom Jobim, Joao Bosco. Chico Buarque de Hollanda, Djavan, Toninho Horta, and Guinga were rich inspiration for Metheny, though he never copied them; rather, he created his own derivations and they were stellar.

Though the Unity Band compositions are, occasionally, interesting, they are not warm and evocative in any way. This is not to suggest that Metheny has lost his passion or his penchant for musicality--rather, he is on a different road trip. The terrain seems...well...dry and desolate.

product_title: City of Heavenly Fire (The Mortal Instruments Book 6)
review_headline: A truly epic and addictive final installment in the Mortal Instruments series!
review_body:
*NO SPOILERS, I PROMISE!*

Oh. My. Goodness. “City of Heavenly Fire” was the most epic and awesome conclusion to the Mortal Instruments series that I could have ever hoped for! It was truly, truly amazing and I absolutely loved reading every single page. All of the characters were beyond exceptional and I loved them the most in this novel. Emma Carstairs and Julian Blackthorn were also extraordinary characters and a wonderful addition to the Shadowhunter clan. I can’t wait to read more about them in the Dark Artifices series!

I loved everything, absolutely everything, about COHF. I loved how there were an abundance of surprises and shocking turns of events throughout that had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. I loved how almost every character’s POV was incorporated, and that I was able to see what they were thinking and feeling at certain points of the story. I was completely enthralled from beginning to end and I experienced a whole spectrum of emotions while reading this book – some good, and others not so good. Everything was so detailed and intriguing, and there was certainly never a dull moment. It also blew my mind that Cassandra Clare managed to incorporate several TID references, and I thought it was freaking awesome that some of the characters from that series made appearances as well. There were many aspects of this story that made me extremely happy, and I truly couldn’t have asked for a better ending than the one that I received. It was just extraordinary, plain and simple.

Be prepared and plan to be surprised throughout this fascinating and intriguing conclusion to one of the most phenomenal series that I have ever read. Cassandra Clare is by far one of the best and most favored authors that I have ever read and she can write absolutely phenomenal conclusions. Fans of TMI will most certainly not be disappointed with “City of Heavenly Fire!”

product_title: Plague Inc.
review_body:
There are a lot of garbage apps out there, addictions in the disguise of games.Plague Inc. is a step above he rest. it's not as rich as some of the strategy titles out there, like those based on boardgames, Pandemic for example, but it's engaging, simple and logical. That logical part is important because the change element is less about trying to push players into micro-trans than it is making sure each game feels a little different.

As a gamer, I can't see myself playing this for hours on end for weeks, but I do like to pull it out once in awhile and try a new tactic, just to see what it's like. And in case you haven't discovered this yet, it's a dark theme, the destruction of humanity and all, but the mayhem is a bit more calculated and numbers than some of he more mature themed games.

product_title: The Power of Your Subconscious Mind
review_headline: Andy Holligan, author of You Are The Problem, You Are The Solution
review_body: This is a very powerful book which explains how powerful our thoughts are and how important it is to think positively. None of us can deny responsibility for where we are in life. We have created our lives and lifestyles by the way we think. Nothing happnes by chance. There is no such thing as good luck or bad luck. There is a reason for everything. (The law of cause and effect) Our thinking is the cause and where we are in life is the effect. Think positively and you get positive results, think negativley and you get negative results. The good news is that regardless of the past, no matter how negative it has been, or how many times we have failed, we can change course at any time and redirect our lives, by changing what we put into our minds and by how we talk to ourselves. Thank you Mr Murphy for giving me the inspiration to get my first book published, and thank you for your valuable insights.

product_title: Riddick (Unrated Director's Cut)
review_body: I have been asking myself is this bad writing, bad acting or bad directing.  The cast is adequate enough to pull off a classic I think, but there is so much wrong with this film.  Vin Diesel is what he is, he plays one character always, so it is up to the director to use him like a hammer, "you don't have to do nothing fancy, just hit the nail" (director's fault there).  Now Vin is absolved so who's next, well the writer, the story seems thrown together hastily with an emphasis on the action sequences and not the plausibility of the scenes or continuity of the stories foundation (writer maybe).  My conclusion is someone with the power to edit this film to pieces, did just that (destroyed it).  I suppose I asked too much of this one, but it was in the shadow of "the Chronicle of Riddick," and that was a fine effort with hopes of an even better squeal.  I would still watch all three films again, and most likely will.

product_title: ...And Out Come The Wolves
review_body:
There are few things in my life that ever qualify as best ever. I have owned this album since it first came out, and have spent a lot of road trips or other miscellaneous time listening to music of all sorts. While on a recent fishing trip, I had this album set to repeat on my iPod. I listened to it for a whole day while hiking in the mountains fishing back country lakes. It dawned on me on the drive home(while still continuing to listen to it) that this is my favorite album of all time, and despite hearing the same songs over and over that day, it never got old.

I have been a Rancid fan for a long time, and have enjoyed their work on almost every album they have made. Bottom line though, "...And Out Come The Wolves" is hands-down their best album, and my personal favorite album of all time, for any genre of music.

product_title: The Music Man
review_headline: All of my kids like the music
review_body:
Part of our American culture. One of those must see movies. So many analogies referenced to this movie. All of my kids like the music. I asked my 17 yo son to join the rest of us in watching it one Sunday. "I've seen it, the first time you made me watch it when I was 12." ...."So watch it again, and refresh your memory." "I still remember every song in there, Mom." ...."Yeah, right!" I said. THen he proceeded to sing the Wells Fargo song. "Not enough?" he asked, then started the Marion the Librarian song. Hmm. "Okay, your free." He ended up on the couch with us for the last half.
My 5 year old pointed to a pretty young woman on the street and said she looked like Marion the Libraian.

Iconic movie.

product_title: The Children Act
review_body:
The best novelists present readers with fully formed, complex characters, and place them in situations that reveal something true about our human condition, or what it means to live. Ian McEwan examines the choice to live or to die in his novel titled, The Children Act. Protagonist Fiona Maye is a judge in the family court in London, and her work life and home life are radically different. About to turn sixty, her childless thirty-five year marriage is strained because of her husband's infidelity. Tension at work accelerates when she is called into an emergency case of a seventeen-year-old boy who has refused a lifesaving blood transfusion for religious reasons. Her visit with the boy pairs two intelligent characters struggling with what it means to live and to die, and the choice to live or die, quickly or slowly. McEwan reveals all this in a compact novel that delighted me from beginning to end.

Rating: Five-star (I love it)

product_title: Gone Girl: A Novel
review_body:
Good story with interesting characters...but no ending. None.I liked the tension between characters...but there's no climax. Simply an abrupt ending...with no resolution.

The book was highly recommended by readers I trust. But, I understand now, where they were coming from. They were still in the middle of the book when they recommended it. They, too, anticipated an ending...of some-sort. They, too, fell for recommendation from people who just had not gotten to the point where the writing stops.

I gave the book two stars for the writing. The description and compelling story-line is well done. There's only one problem, but I consider it to be a big problem (and I think most readers do), there's NO ending. The writer simply abruptly stops writing. I actually turned the next page anticipating the next chapter and audibly uttered, \\\\\What the..No, this can't be all of it.\\\\\" But, it was all of it. No ending, no conclusion, no resolution. The writer simply stopped writing. What? Did the writer just get bored? Why put all of that time into a story, then simply leave off the ending.

Would've been a five star book with at least an attempt at an ending."

product_title: AmazonBasics Backpack for SLR/DSLR Cameras and Accessories - Black
review_headline: Good product for the Price. Beginning Photographer.
review_body: I purchased this backpack a little over a month ago for my Canon 7d and my 28-135mm lense. I read some reviews complaining about the materials. I think that for the price of $25 this is a very good bag. The only reason I returned it is because when I was about to go out of the country, I found myself having to take another bag for my computer and other items, so I decided to return it to buy the Lowepro Fastpack 250 Camera/Laptop backpack at $25 more in an Amazon flash sale. The Amazon backpack is light, has enough space for your camera and lenses and has straps for chest and waist. Like I said, I used it for a short time, so I cannot accurately talk about its durability, but the straps and the zippers seemed to work OK.
