product_title: Yen Path: Taking Steps Towards What You Want in Life
review_headline: Nice reminder to focus on the big picture
review_body:
Yen Path is a guide to becoming your best self through a combination of yoga philosophy and general life coaching techniques. Gallagher, who is a life coach and yoga instructor, shares her method of reconnecting with yourself and mapping a plan to achieve your goals. Full of step-by-step instructions, Yen Path guides the reader through visualizing your dreams and desires to setting up an action plan and everything in between. Charts and worksheets are easy to use and really encourage the reader to take proactive steps rather than just absorbing the author's instructions.

While I really enjoyed the overall concept and approach, the book was slow moving and seemed disjointed in places. Gallagher certainly knows and believes in her method, however, it seemed at times that she was overwhelmed by the amount of useful information she wanted to share. The author spent quite a lot of time preparing the reader for what was to come instead of just digging in to the information. Also, some life examples seemed rather large to take on for a general life/self-help book. For example, in a section titled \\\\\Reconciling Conflict Inputs\\\\\", Gallagher provides the example of an individual who has a job and a family but wishes to quit his job to travel. \\\\\"You know that if you tell your wife about your plan, then she will be angry. Now you begin to feel resentment...\\\\\" Gallagher suggests, however, her remedy is to \\\\\"think differently\\\\\" and the \\\\\"clear the mental clutter\\\\\" using meditation.

Overall, Yen Path is helpful when taken lightly. It's a nice reminder to focus on the big picture or big life goals and to be present in your life, to keep your values in mind and to let them guide your actions and beliefs. The worksheets were fun to do and were a nice exercise in visualizing goals and what is important."

product_title: Jane's Melody
review_body: This is one of the best books I have read in awhile.Had a hard time putting it down please put out more books as soon as possible.

product_title: Lean UX: Applying Lean Principles to Improve User Experience
review_body: Good content on agile design. It helps me apply the practices to the actual product work. If there is a consolidated worksheet for the whole process will make this book an A+.

product_title: The Life She Left Behind (The Santina Crown)
review_body:
Got it when it was FREE which was the better price for this short read.

So Taj and Angelina father conspired to work out a MOC b/w Taj and Angelina. She knew nothing about it, but she did not want to marry him under those terms even though she was in lust, love, w/ him. Angelina runs in to Taj where she is working as a nanny. He can't believe she gave up all to be a nanny. Angelina decided self- respect was priceless and she wanted it. Angelina thought Taj had loved her but apparently he loved a merger more. He is honest about what he truly wanted. Angelina thinks perhaps she can play a game w/ their lust and finally achieve what she didn't get three years ago. Taj seems all for it too. After all he had suffered when she walked. So while she appears harder than she was before he can't, but does w/ Angelina. She uses him then leaves. Forced to marry and learn that he would have replaced her as his wife pretty easily before, yet he hadn't. She doesn't always give in to him easily, but he soon realizes that he does care for her. He soon works out his problems, decides to set her free, but confesses love along the way. It was nice that Taj hadn't been w/ any other women those three years. He did feel something for her he just didn't know what it was at the time. It was a nice, short story.

product_title: Hold On My Heart
review_body: This is just the kind of book you need by the pool or at the beach.  Totally a fun read.  Highly recommend it if you're just looking for something casual and fun to pass a lazy vacation afternoon.

product_title: 8 Ways To Accelerate Your Photography: How To Speed Up The Learning Curve
review_body: This is an amazing book, with easy to understand text and fabulous photographs. I have read many photography books in my lifetime but this is one of the best. I am looking forward to putting the advice into practice.

product_title: The Outsider: My Autobiography
review_body: Jimmy Connors The Outsider is an excellent read for anyone who lived through the great tennis years of the 70/80s.

product_title: Gone with the Wind
review_headline: Realizing what  GWTW really represents because of  having Kindle
review_body:
I did grow up with GWTW. I was 6 years old when it first came upon the scene. I read and re-read it and loved it every time I read it, which was often for about 30 years. Life came along and I stopped reading it for over 40 years. I just got the Kindle edition and settled in to visit and enjoy an old and dear friend.
What had I been thinking? Where had my sense of right and wrong been? How could I ever have been so shallow? so insensitive?
The book of my youth, that I quoted and encouraged anyone who had never read it to read, I know now, is a virulent, racist screed, tucked away in massive doses in what is actually, actually, a fascinating and riveting story.
If I were given to book-burning, which I am not, this horror would be the first on the bonfire. I'm trying to do a major mea culpa and tell all of the nieces, friends, casual acquaintances I have, over the years encouraged, even almost insisted, they read.
I am still shaking my head over how easily I skipped over, ignored, just didn't react to what is among the ugliest racism in print in the 20th century. I'm not discouraging people from reading GWTW. The younger among us could see how our country's attitudes have changed since this book was and still is acclaimed, the Treyvon Martin trial fiasco being, hopefully, the anomaly I hope it to be.
To be a little more specific, Scarlett's beloved Mammy is referred to twice as having ape-like expressions on her face...yes, \\\\\ape\\\\\" is the word of Mitchell's choice, not Scarlett's........remember, this was written in the 1930s, not the 1860s....and so it goes on and on, in all its racist poison....."

product_title: Service: A Navy SEAL at War
review_body: It is well written and I enjoyed it very much. American citizens need to know what our soldiers are facing over there

product_title: Fatal Mistake (The Fatal Series Book 6)
review_body: Love her style of writing,This book was totaly riviting and held my interest from start to finish.was a great read

product_title: My New Orleans, Gone Away: A Memoir of Loss and Renewal
review_body: This is a finely written, closely observed memoir that deals intelligently not just with the personal dimension of growing up in America in the 1940s and 50s but with the larger social changes of that era and since. The author brings humor, passion and rigor to his illuminating story. (Full disclosure: I'm in it as a friend)

product_title: Heart of a Donovan (The Donovans Book 9)
review_body: Catching up with the Donovans was romantic & suspenseful. Now on to the mystery surrounding the elder Donovans. I cannot wait to read the story on that one. I hope the author writes a story on the elders sort of like the Ramsey elders. Overall I couldn't put the book down. Can't wait for the next one.

product_title: Attempting Normal
review_headline: could not put it down, sad that it's over
review_body: This book is a window into the scary brain and colorful life of talented comedian and storyteller, Marc Maron. He's sensitive, self-reflective (is that a word?), neurotic, sometimes a little psychotic, but always funny.

product_title: Qsymia Plan for Weight Loss: A Practical Guide To Using the New Diet Medication
review_body: I was very disappointed in this book.  I expected more information regarding the recommended diet and got very little.  The price was very expensive for what the book disclosed.  Not a good buy at all.  I cannot believe it was so highly recommended.

product_title: Foolish
review_body: It's hard to write a decent review without giving the story away. The story revolves around two closeted men. It includes several detailed intimate scenes. The author gets right to the point. I wasn't too impressed!

product_title: Believe in Me (The Golden Children Book 1)
review_body: Decent premise spoiled by less than stellar execution and a certain melodramatic style that does the author no credit. Maybe an editor with an axe could have helped.

product_title: Coolest Chapter Books for Kids Sampler
review_headline: No complete stories, only the first few chapters of 4 books in this sample.
review_body: I was disappointed that the 'free' sampler does not finish the stories.  I got this so my granddaughter can practice reading and I understood that it would be only portions of the books (not the books in their entirety) but I assumed some of the middle chapters would be eliminated and the samples would skip to the end so at least there would be resolution.  This doesn't happen you are left hanging so you must buy (or borrow the book) if you want to know the end.  The stories and humorous and engaging and my granddaughter did enjoy what she read.

product_title: The Ugly Duckling (Illustrated)
review_headline: Why the book the ugly duckling
review_body: This book was a very good book for kids to understand the true meaning of excepting others as they are and not trying to change them because they different. Kids need to Learn the true meaning of loving others . People should the heart of people and not just the outside this was an amazing book for kids to understand

product_title: Belly Fat Diet Book [Second Edition]
review_headline: A Guide to Belly Fat and Recipes
review_body: Although [[ASIN:B00BNVOWHM Belly Fat Diet Book [Second Edition]]] contains some typos and layout issues, it provides a good introduction as to what belly fat is and some tricks on how to get rid of it.

product_title: Finding Hope
review_body: Beautiful story that was engaging and spiritual in nature. The plot moved along in a manner that kept my interest, even though I knew the hero would ultimately come to salvation in addition to \\\\\getting the girl\\\\\"."

product_title: Hornblower and the Hotspur Vol3 (Hornblower Saga)
review_body: Lots of action and fast moving plot.  A little more detail about period history and sailing terms would be helpful.

product_title: No Problem - The Upside of Saying No
review_body:
I found this to be a simple to use guide to using several very effective techniques. It's easy to read and easy to follow.
The author obviously knows her material well and at the same time has a personal touch that makes me feel that I'm being spoken to by a human being with flaws rather than by someone who's got it all worked out.

product_title: Gut Check: The Inside Truth on Restoring Your Digestive Health
review_body:
I found this guide to be thorough and practical. What I like the most about it is that it does a thorough job in approaching digestion from different angles. You can thus understand how it works and get practical tips on how to optimize it. Not only that, but the book goes into the common digestion problems and provides effective solutions.

All of us are confronted with challenges related to digestion, at least from time to time. And there are a lot of nutrition books out there, but very few focus on digestion. I think we have a lot to gain in terms of health if we understand the digestion process better and act accordingly. This guide really nails all the key elements related to digestion. Recommended!

product_title: Making Sense of Your High Sensitivity
review_headline: A helpful inside view on challenges, plus resources to thrive
review_body: Qualities of the personality trait can help fuel our creative work and a fulfilling life, but being highly sensitive can also be physically and emotionally challenging in many ways. Cliff Harwin details a number of his experiences in school including shaming by a teacher - not a unique event, of course, but for those of us who are highly sensitive, these kinds of experiences can have an enduring impact on our adult lives. He also writes candidly about some of his health problems and finding appropriate and supportive health care professionals. In the section \\\\\Your Road Map to a Happy Life\\\\\" he provides a number of practical tips, and also has a section that lists resources to help highly sensitive people thrive."

product_title: Sweet Thing
review_body: I loved this book, from the beginning to the end. I can't wait to see if there will be a second book. Maybe Will's POV??!! :) I suggest this book to all my friends and they love it.

product_title: The Pact: A Love Story
review_body: One of my absolute favorite books, by far. The ultimate love story that pulled at my heart and left me turning page after page. Wonderful!

product_title: The Engine 2 Diet: The Texas Firefighter's 28-Day Save-Your-Life Plan that Lowers Cholesterol and Burns Away the Pounds
review_body: Being legally blind, I was hoping for some meal plans, which would have been very helpful to me since reading is very difficult for me.

product_title: Terror at The Sterling
review_body: The imagery in this story is phenomenal. In hindsight, this may have been a bad idea to read before trying to sleep because I'm sure I'll have a hard time forgetting the horror show that was painted perfectly within the text of this book.

review_body: This was an amazing love story with many unforeseen twists and turns. I would recommend this book to anyone wanting to escape their world and get trapped in the world of Androcoles and Araceli. There is a part 2 and a prequel coming soon...I can't wait!!!

product_title: One Second After (A John Matherson Novel)
review_body: This book was too close to what could happen for my liking, it was written very well and definitely made you think. I liked it very much the way you like a medicine you need!!

product_title: Rebecca's Lost Journals, Volume 1: The Seduction
review_body:
Excellent companion to book #1 [[ASIN:1476726043 If I Were You (Inside Out Trilogy)]] In this short Journal, Rebecca basically describes meeting a man so powerful he owns the air around him. Heads, both male and female, turn when he walks in a room...conversation practically ceases. He's someone so controlling he exudes masculine power. It emanates off of him. He's arrogant and devilishly handsome and Rebecca never names him.

In this Journal, she describes wanting to know and understand more about herself. So she allows herself to become involved with this powerful, controlling, mystery man. And her life is no longer her own. He consumes her.

product_title: Damocles
review_headline: I don't understand the bad reviews
review_body: I really like sci fi but know nothing about physics and space travel so really don't care about the \\\\\accuracy\\\\\" of any references in this book to those concepts that some reviewers got fired up about.  Like any of us are going to be traveling to another planet any time soon.  What I thought was really interesting was the description of the humanoids on the non Earth planet and the development of communication/relationships between them and the people who had their origins in Earth.  Yes, there were some differences, but in the end, people are people it seems."

product_title: The Key to Personal Peace
review_body: I really enjoyed reading this book. I have to say it helped me a lot now that I am feeling troubled and confused. After reading this I feel awake. Easy to read and understand regardless of what religion or denomination.

product_title: Origami Ornaments: The Ultimate Kusudama Book
review_body: Someone should teach this writer how to teach.  Vague descriptions at critical points when lesser known methods are used, but rather lengthy when describing extremely basic concepts.  This is the only origami instruction I've attempted and failed. Miserably. Repeatedly.  There are so many awesome designs inside and it is extremely frustrating that I can't find the patterns anywhere else-except for a few which I was able to build in little time after having found better instructions.

product_title: Jaded (Rock Star Trilogy Book 1)
review_body:
I'm a fan of these type of books so it is so easy to like Scarlett. She is the ultimate! Her parents knew she was talented and her career took off by the time she was 15. She has recorded 4 albums and is already on her way to setting records in the business. She felt like she wanted to go and finish school in person. So she tells everyone she wants to experience her senior year. Well that doesn't go over so good but at 19 she can do what she wants. So she tells her Manager Dad to kiss off and she leaves for Hope, Florida. She has a home there and within a week she is on her way to NORMAL.

Well Scarlett Ryan is a millionaire rock star who is known all over. It's a very interesting take in school and how she sees the people who are now her peers. Some recognize her but some are confused and don't think it is her, the star. The first people she meets are half-brothers Stephan and Ethan. I love Stephan Montgomery. He's a little full of himself and is not intimidated by Scarlett. He teases her calling her Blondie, but you can see he is not as tough as he appears. She can't stop thinking about him or the fact that she never really had a boyfriend. Their relationship is cute and you WILL enjoy it.

What I loved was that the message get a diploma. Then I loved how grounded she was. She realizes that she has screwed up, not giving things away, but she uses it as a learning experience. I appreciate that the author doesn't make it a story of excess. It is about a true talent, musical genius. What are you waiting for? go read it!

product_title: The Last Swordmage: The Swordmage Trilogy: Book 1 (Magic of Solendrea)
review_body:
The good
-first part of the book is ok, interesting magical system
-characters are cliched but appealing

The bad
-the entire second half has such huge holes in the plot that even hardened pulp sci fi lovers such as my wife and i found it impossible to maintain the suspension of disbelief.
-fantasy world created, while interesting in the first half, falls apart completely by the second half. As soon as the narrative scope pulls back from the village where it starts, the writer is unable to create a bigger political and social structure that is in any way coherent. I'm not asking for Ursula LeGuin, but this book lacks even the usual standard fantasy empire.
- many many errors in spelling and some in grammar.

Sigh. We wanted to like this book, but couldn't.

product_title: Society’s Collapse:  The Bug Out. (Book 1) (Society's Collapse 2)
review_body:
I just completed reading this book and was amazed at how it captured my reading interests. I am an avid reader of books such as the Vince Flynn series and found this book to be every bit as exciting. As the action continued, I couldn't read fast enough to get to the next event!!

Terrific cast of characters with multiple story lines that converge at various points along the way.

The ending will leave you wanting and waiting for the next in the series.

Highly recommended.

review_body: I really like this whole series.  I wish that the next book would come out quicker than it is scheduled.  The book is left with a cliffhanger ending and I want to know what happens next.

review_body: This book tells what troubles the Amish went through to protect their religion from the government trying to take it away from them.

product_title: Alpha Girl (The Wolfling Saga Book 1)
review_body:
Thank you to the author for providing me this book.

4 stars. (I liked it).

Alpha girl tells us a story of werewolves. I liked the way the concept of werewolves returned to the old roots where being bitten by one, makes you one too, and you don't transform at will, but only once a month.

Alpha girl left me with mixed feelings. For instance it had a lot of potential but somehow I was disappointed with some things. Still, it is rather refreshing in the genre, which I appreciate.
Things I liked:
- The writing is not tiring and it is easy to read.
- \\\\\Taboo\\\\\" theme teacher x student.
- Hero does not sparkle, is not a depressed Greek god, it's an older guy and he's not stupidly rich.
- Heroine was a loner with \\\\\"friends\\\\\" and was able to interact with them.
- Heroine´s relationship with her parents. It was love-hate and I could identify myself with her feelings.
- The worries of the hero, which reflects the way society sees a romantic relationship between adult-teenager.

Things I disliked:
- The overuse of Mr.Stone´s nicknames to the heroine \\\\\"sweet, love\\\\\" etc. It felt so right at first, but so lame at the end. It made me feel like he was her daddy.
- How easily one character forgave the other after the major twist was revealed. I was expecting more angst and fight.
- How Rose started as an amazing mature girl and slowly became a complete brat.
- The feeling that being the \\\\\"alpha\\\\\" is not good, it makes the relationship seem forced between mates, in which one cannot \\\\\"disobey\\\\\".

The plot was not completely original, but it was not cliché either, so I praise the author for it. I see a lot of potential to be developed in a sequel. I'm expecting an amazing sequel."

product_title: Ice Breaker Games (Ice Breakers Book 1)

product_title: Golden
review_body:
I went into Golden with high, I mean HIGH expectations. I expected to be swept off my feet, bawl my eyes out and just feel like my heart was ripped out of my chest... none of that happened. Now let me explain...

I loved the main character Parker. I thought she was one of the most realistic and raw characters I have seen in a book in quite some time. Her emotions and actions were just so true for that time in her life. She was irrational at times but it led her to a good place and the struggle she had with finding herself I think is something that a lot of people will relate to. The coming of age aspect of this novel was done exceptionally well. I also really enjoyed her best friend, Kat. Their relationship was done very well in my opinion. Kat had such honest emotions with the fact that Parker would be leaving for university and she would be remaining in town. The friendship between Parker and Kat was probably one of my favorite things about Golden.

The plot, for me, was so predictable. I just seen everything that was going to happen coming well before it did. I'm not sure why... and I'm not sure if I was supposed to but it really kept me from loving the story. I obviously won't go into the details because these are major plot points that we are talking about but... ah, it frustrates me that I wasn't surprised. The story about Julianna and Shane is just heart wrenching. It's a really, really sad part of the book. I didn't openly cry but I felt this ache in my chest the more Parker read Julianna's diary. To think that someone so young had her fire snuffed out... oh, it's just so sad.

My other love for Golden was the writing. I adore Jessi Kirby's writing style. She brings you entirely into the story and carries you along with it. It's like music. Between her writing and the characters Golden was saved for me.

Now don't mistake that this isn't a wonderful story, it is. And I did like it but I think my high expectations crushed this one for me, which is unfortunate. I wanted to love this. It's well worth the read, especially if you love contemporary. And believe me ... there are a ton of AMAZING reviews for this. Take mine with a grain of salt.

review_headline: The Way the economy and money actually work
review_body: This book describes the way the economy and money actually work. This is about MMT and fiat currency and the way money works in a sovereign government that issues it's own currency. review_headline: Great narrative approach to all things psych and life

If you're looking for a science book explaining interesting facets of life but hate the scientific jargon, read this book for the great narrative.

I'm just glad everything turned out good.

product_title: Have No Shame (When civil rights and forbidden love collide)
review_headline: Legendary Love Story Meets Devistating Slice of History
review_body:
Have No Shame has easily moved its way into my top 10 list of favorite books ever read. This book is such an important dissection of such a tragic time in history. This book takes place in Forrest Town, Arkansas in the late 60's, when segregation \\\\\should\\\\\" have been on its way out, but was still holding its ugly roots in some areas of the south in particular.

This unique and lovely story is positioned so well from Alison's point of view -- a simple farm-girl who graduates high school and is about to marry her high school sweet heart when a devastating event jars her conscious and causes her to really open her eyes and see how African Americans were being treated in her small town by her \\\\\"people.\\\\\" Having been raised in an environment of racial prejudice, in a town that has no intention of accepting the civil rights of all people, Alison is forced to decide between the love of her old-school father and accepting her \\\\\"place\\\\\" (as well as to stand beside her fiancé, Jimmy Lee, who has a few dark secrets she's beginning to suspect) OR to stand up for what she's beginning to believe in - that people shouldn't be treated differently based on the color of their skin.

What makes this book stand apart from other books about this topic, is just the pure beauty and flow of Foster's language. The book has a beautiful, southern cadence and a simple, clean way of story-telling. From page one I was drawn into Alison's character and could see her as she took those fateful steps. My heart ached for her when she was put in horrifying situations that she wanted to take back and felt shame for bearing witness to. You could literally feel her heart aching from being torn by what she knows from how she's been raised, and what she knows to be true based on what her heart is telling her. And Foster has a wonderful gift with her turn-of-phrase, and had some lines that just left me speechless they were so wonderfully written.

Enter Jackson. Swoon worthy, sweet, strong, handsome, kind-hearted, well-mannered, charming Jackson. It's not a spoiler to say that the other side of this story, woven beautifully with Alison's personal growth in regards to fighting for civil liberty, is the love story that blossoms slowly, and beautifully, and heart-breakingly between her and Jackson. You want so much for them to have a happy ending right away, without going through the real life tribulations that are bound to happen with a forbidden love in a racially charged town where citizens are taking the law into their own hands for the \\\\\"safety\\\\\" of the streets against \\\\\"those people.\\\\\" I was hanging onto every word, aching with Alison as doors seemed to close for her. Rooting when she started to grow up and away from the beliefs she was raised on. And cheered when she began listening to her heart and trying to change status quo for future generations. And sobbed when she let Jackson walk away from her after a conversation at one point early on in the book. (This was me: \\\\\"Noooo! Run after him you idiot!\\\\\")

Equally as deep and beautiful in this book is Alison's relationship with her mother. Watching it unfold the way it did was such a privilege. I loved a line she said about learning more about her mother in those five minutes than she had in eighteen years of living with her. Simply beautiful. And her sister, Maggie, was such a strong and memorable character as well. Foster just has a way of making you fall deeply entrenched in your passion for the character's plight and being emotionally invested in their outcomes.

I don't want to spoil the ending, but Foster did a wonderful job portraying the reality of the situation, and that is - things don't change overnight. Not when there is hate born on generations of discrimination that run through a town. But, my oh my, the courage these people showed to be a part of history, do the right thing, and affect change - it was simply breathtaking to bear witness to.

Andnot ever can I recall an interracial couple who will live on as a most beloved romantic couple whose epic love story will never be forgotten by readers. But for me, this is a couple whose love story I will celebrate for a very long time. It's just one of those stories where you get done reading and you think, damn! I wish these characters were real. I want to be friends with Maggie. I want to sit down and talk with Alison and Jackson. I want to see Jimmy Lee go down in flames. This was one villain I can't say I felt any love for (and I kinda like a good villain).

This was easily one of the best books I've read in a very, very long time. And Alison and Jackson's story will always hold a place in my heart. I hope you enjoy it every bit as much as I did.

Oh, and I read it in both versions (with southern dialect in the narrative and without) and I can honestly say I LOVED both versions equally.ver can I recall an interracial couple who will live on as a most beloved romantic couple whose epic love story will never be forgotten by readers. But for me, this is a couple whose love story I will celebrate for a very long time. It's just one of those stories where you get done reading and you think, damn! I wish these characters were real. I want to be friends with Maggie. I want to sit down and talk with Alison and Jackson. I want to see Jimmy Lee go down in flames. This was one villain I can't say I felt any love for (and I kinda like a good villain).

This was easily one of the best books I've read in a very, very long time. And Alison and Jackson's story will always hold a place in my heart. I hope you enjoy it every bit as much as I did.

Oh, and I read it in both versions (with southern dialect in the narrative and without) and I can honestly say I LOVED both versions equally."

review_body: I chose this rating because of the personal story that was told.  It was a great story and the author took a brilliant snapshot of  an icon in America.  He featured great photographs and commentary that gave the reader a rare candid look at Mr. Jobs.  This is one of the finest methods to reveal the true mind of Steve Jobs.

product_title: Have No Shame (When civil rights and forbidden love collide)
review_body:
I love this book!! I was hooked from the moment I read the first sentence. I didn't want to put "Have No Shame" down until I was read it all, I was so caught up in it.
Melissa Foster is an amazing author - I feel like I am "in the story". She creates a such a vivid picture in my mind with her stories I feel like I'm right there along with the characters.
I miss the "people" she created when I finish her books. I felt that even more deeply after reading this book.
I felt a deep connection to Alison, her love of her "Daddy" who was stuck on keeping things the same & not supoortng civil rights, the fact that she had a true kind heart that only "saw" people for who they were, not the color of their skin.
Melissa Foster captured the civil rights movement perfectly, the fact that many southern states refused to accept change, the ignorance & hatred that spawned the KKK & the courage, faith, hope & love that people fighting for civil rights had to try & bring change to their towns.
You will love this book too, I know it :)

product_title: All Due Respect (The Anthology Book 1)
review_body: I've been reading any amount of shorts lately, yet \\\\\All Due Respect\\\\\" found plenty of new ways to surprise and delight me. Plenty of themes and backdrops are familiar (in particular, I've had enough meth-fueled characters and situations to last me a good while). For me, though, the standout attribute of this collection is the way it alternated from grimness to a warped levity. No clinkers here, and though there are many standouts, the entries that come to mind right now are those from Garnett Elliott, Tom Pitts, Jim Wilsky, and McDroll. I'd say I was familiar with about half the authors here, and so it's good to have exposure to so many other new ones."

product_title: Jack Daniels Series - Three Thriller Novels (Dirty Martini #4, Fuzzy Navel #5, Cherry Bomb #6)
review_body: Murder and humor, who knew the two could be mixed. I especially liked the last two books in this series. Despite the downright seriousness of the plot, I found myself laughing out loud at some of the character's remarks. Mr Konrath outdid himself in mixing serial killing and humor. He did this without skipping a beat or becoming lost in the sequence of the plot. If you like a fast paced, intriguing plot and you also have a sense of humor you will love this series. In addition to a great sequence of hit and miss tries to capture a serial killer, you will find a cat that attacks people, a monkey that assaults people, and characters with great lines that will leave you smiling. I'm already a fan of Mr Konrath and can't wait to start the next novel in his series.

product_title: Powder of Sin
review_body:
I absolutely loved this book! Here we have a smart, independent heroine who isn't a Mary Sue, a hero who is introspective and honorable without being in any way boring, and an aphrodisiac that actually works--overwhelmingly and on everyone who encounters it--and the heroine's quest to keep it safe and NOT use it.

Yeah, you weren't expecting that, were you?

It's that last bit that makes Powder of Sin so unique and riveting. Instead of selling the drug to the highest bidder or using it to entrap Gideon who she desires more every day, Rosalie seeks to protect society from the harm it could cause. Gideon, who is rather like the male version of a lady's nurse/chaperone for a man who makes the most outrageous rake you've ever imagined seem tame, joins in to help her because the worst thing he can imagine is the powder falling into his charge's possession. No female under the age of 101 would be safe!

Kate Rothwell is one of my favorite authors and this story is an excellent example why. Her characters are realistic and compelling, her knowledge of the historical period is flawless, and the combination of humor, drama, and heat is just right. I can't recommend this book enough!

product_title: Fit to Endure the Fire
review_headline: You'll Keep Going Back For More
review_body:
This is a book that you will highlight and keep returning to. It has given me wonderful practical tips on how to deal with the challenges of life. I love chapter 3: You Can't Avoid The Test. This chapter really helped me understand the purpose of challenges and tests. If you really desire growth in every area of your life you have to be willing to endure the tests of life. As Pastor Hill put it, "God isn't interested in excuses...He is looking for people who will match challenges with faith in action". The fire comes to make you better, if you let it.

A definite must read!

product_title: The Lost Symbol: Featuring Robert Langdon
review_body: I have read all of Dan Brown books and if this had been the first one I read, I would not have read a second.

product_title: The Aviator's Wife: A Novel
review_headline: Finally Anne Morrow Lindbergh is heard
review_body:
I have read so many biographies about the famous Lucky Lindy. I toured the courthouse in NJ where the trial for their baby's kidnap and murder was held. I talked to a man who, as a child, had sat in his mother's lap in that courtroom during the trial. I visited the home and saw the window from which the baby had been stolen. I stayed in the bungalow on Captiva Island where Anne wrote Gifts from the Sea.

And finally in this book I heard her voice and understood her story. Thank you Melanie, for bringing this wonderful and much-overlooked woman to life. She was a heroine in her own right.

product_title: Brain Rules: 12 Principles for Surviving and Thriving at Work, Home, and School
review_headline: Every educator of any kind should study this book, as should every parent of a school child.
review_body: John Medina has put his finger on many many aspects of learning that were not even contemplated when public education was first introduced.  Sadly, the founding model of public education has so thoroughly permeated it, that almost none of the modern discoveries about learning can be implemented in a meaningful way.  Even modern digital and communication technologies are being used like adding digital gages, GPS, and entertainment systems to horse drawn buggies.  As Medina says, the education system must be changed in a revolutionary way if we are to remedy its failings.  30% dropout rates, a scientifically illiterate public, college graduates who have no useful knowledge of our country's history, 17th and lower placement of our very best students vs the rest of the world...These are unacceptable results from our nation's education system.

product_title: Undressed (The Manhattanites)
review_body:
This was a pretty hot read. There’s a threesome scene that our heroine witnesses that was pretty hot and the chemistry between Masi and Lex is tangible. However, I found myself more invested in the storyline than the romance. The people around Lex and Masi were fun and compelling, and I really liked Lex herself for the most part, but it took me a while to warm up to Masi because he seemed a strange combination of gentleman and jerk.

I wasn’t wholly invested in the story, but even so, I have to admit that when things got critical I was crying for Lex and wanting to scream at Masi for being a little naïve in such a situation. However, the ending was sweet and adorable and I came out firmly on the approving side for Masi.

Overall, while the sex was hot, it was regarded much too casually for the majority of the book and the plot was pretty predictable. While I ultimately enjoyed the book, it just didn’t captivate me.

A fast, easy read, Undressed is a very steamy read with fun characters and an interesting fashion scene. If you’re looking for a pretty light hearted romance with a little kink, don’t miss this one.

**I received a complimentary copy of the book in exchange for an honest review.**

product_title: Legends of Amun Ra-The Emerald Tablet
review_body:
Freaking cool! That is how all books like this should start. I mean odd names, glowing pillars, emerald tablets, ancient mythology, cult-like cultures- what more could one ask for?

I really enjoyed this book. It was well written. The plot was unique and original. The characters were well developed. I loved the character arcs. I felt like Josh really spent time getting to know his characters before he put his pen to paper.

There were twists and turns and each step of the way you connected with the characters. Josh threw unexpected plot twists at you and made you want to keep reading. I love the beginning and by the end I wanted to get my hands on the next one and read until there was a complete end. Even my husband had to borrow this one... meaning he snuck off with it and hoarded it in the car until he had read it and got caught putting it back. He loved it too.

I highly recommend this book. It's a great read for anyone looking for a new take on myths, adventure, action, alter-realities, and SO MUCH MORE! Pick it up today!!

*I received this book in exchange for an honest review*

product_title: The Book Thief
review_headline: An amazing and interesting piece of writing.
review_body:
I loved the format this author used in pulling together a poignant story with a young girl as the protagonist. The place her books played in her own survival and development, and the helping of others was brilliant.
I thought the character development was well-done. I had a very good sense of each person's place in the story.
This book gave me a sense of the life of the German people during the Hitler era, the fears, the surviving, the mixed emotions and thoughts as all were pulled into such a crazy time and trying to maintain their own sense of integrity.

product_title: An Irish Country Wedding: A Novel (Irish Country Books Book 7)
review_body:
I love this whole series of books. Patrick Taylor transports you to a slower time in history that is truly enjoyable.
The characters are well defined, quirky, but realistic.
I can't wait for his next book to be published.

product_title: Viking
review_headline: Slow to start, complex to finish
review_body: Viking is set sometime in the future, when inter-stellar travel is possible and groups of "vikings" are sent to distant planets to obtain resources. But it's more complicated than that, the story follows a complex set of characters that don't intersect for a very long time. The concept is great, but the plot is a little too difficult to follow along with.

review_body: This was a great short read.  We have just recently had to put our dog to sleep.  It was one of the hardest day in my life, but now I am reminded to enjoy the times we had with her.  I know she knew she was our \\\\\queen\\\\\".  I recommend this to every dos lover, but get the Kleenex out."

Terrific book, well worth reading!

product_title: The Good Lawyer: A Novel
review_headline: Another legal thriller perhaps, but a good one
review_body:
I will confess to liking legal thrillers. This page turner was no excpetion.

I'm not too sure why they all have to be struggling legal aid lawyers to start off with but nevertheless, the plot is good and the pages keep turning quite fast. Benigno writes well and keeps you intriqued from page one. If I had to look for fault it might be that one had to concentrate in order to decipher the real case or the main plot amongst the fillers.

The formula works, a struggling lawyer, a little romance and some life threatening situations. In this case add a father in law...a break-up and make-up and even an organsied crime boss and you have it all. No this isn't up there with the best but it still makes a good read and the kindle versions offers very good value for money with this book.

product_title: Start Your Own Photography Business!
review_body:
I really enjoyed this short book, reading it in a couple of sittings.

It's clear the author really knows and enjoys his craft, and makes the process of setting up as a photographer seem almost straightforward and even fun. The book is well-organized, and there's a wealth of information here, with informative headings including:

-Dispelling Myths: You do not need expensive equipment to get started.
-What sort of photography should you pursue?
-Marketing Your Services: Create local partnerships with existing businesses.
-Pricing Your Services.
-Expanding Your Business..

The book is part just the facts listing of steps to building your own photography business, and part encouraging account of the author's journey from teen with a new camera to professional photographer.

The admonitions that it doesn't take too much money to start the business, and there is always room for another photographer, may seem disingenuous to some, what with today's economic climate and the plethora of expensive gadgets waiting to tempt novice and professional alike, but the basis is true. For each type and level of photographer, there is a different clientele, and one need only go as fast or as far as seems comfortable.

Good advice, plainly spoken, with enough detail to enable the enthusiast to carry on alone and build a good foundation.

product_title: Scandalous (Scandalous Series Book 1)
review_headline: Scandalous was definitely an appropriate title!
review_body:
3.5 Stars but the last 25% bumped it up to four:0)

Okay so this was a different kind of read for me, not bad, but not, oh my God I loved it. The first half was good but I kept waiting patiently for something to happen, someone to make a move, some action if you will, so in a good way, it kept my interest, but in a bad way, I was like come on already lol. After the halfway point things started to happen and it got a little intense and somewhat sexy, then there was some suspense thrown in about 75% of the way through and it made me get antsy and want to finish the story.

Scandalous is an appropriate title for this story where preacher meets painter.

Abby and Jack knew each other in high school but when something happens that makes Abby run away she does just that and decides to become a preacher. Ten years or so later she has gotten herself in some hot water and is kicked out for a year. She has nothing, no money to amount to anything, no food and the only thing she does have is her friend, Kate. She ends up staying with her and has to find a job that can help her as well as pay off her outrageous debts.
Abby decides that she will interview at a gallery only to discover the painter that is known as Jonathan Gray is actually Jack from all those years ago.

Mesmerized by his paintings and of course him, she realizes that those long ago feelings are still there and she doesn't know what to do. Jack decides to offer her the job and so she hesitantly accepts. Their friendship is rekindled and she confides in him.

I got frustrated here because you could see the torment they were putting themselves through and the intensity of their feelings that neither one would act on until.....

The suggestion, his idea, was the beginning and the end. It consumed me in ways I couldn't have imagined. The idea was like Jack in every way-completely tempting and completely forbidden.

I really liked Jack and once I got to know him I adored him and in the end he made me mad but it all worked out. It was a quick read and it could have been longer. Some things seem to be rushed and there was no angsty buildup in my opinion.

With all of the above being said do I think you should read it? The answer is yes especially if you like art. I personally had a hard time connecting with the characters but that doesn't mean you won't. It obviously held my interest with a variety of things that happened and a few I didn't see coming which made it a plus for me. So my review again is just my opinion and my opinion only. Always keep in mind that what interests one may not interest another. Happy reading :0)I got to know him I adored him and in the end he made me mad but it all worked out. It was a quick read and it could have been longer. Some things seem to be rushed and there was no angsty buildup in my opinion.

With all of the above being said do I think you should read it? The answer is yes especially if you like art. I personally had a hard time connecting with the characters but that doesn't mean you won't. It obviously held my interest with a variety of things that happened and a few I didn't see coming which made it a plus for me. So my review again is just my opinion and my opinion only. Always keep in mind that what interests one may not interest another. Happy reading :0)

review_body: A short no frills account of the lady found in Cresent Lake, it satisfied my curiosity, but there wasn't much filler about the characters

review_body: This is the starter book for a great series. Once you start the first book you will have to read all three. The author is very armature, but the story itself is wonderful!

product_title: Day by Day Armageddon: Shattered Hourglass
review_body: My husband waited so long for this book and was extremely disappointed. For some reason, the author to a different route with his writing style and it just didn't seem to work. The first two books of this series are written as the main character's journal. You got to read day by day what was happening, his thoughts, his ideas and it was like being in his head. This book, which is supposed to be the last of 3 has three different stories going and is written as if narrated by someone else. This series was so unique because of the original writing style and the plausible story line, but my hubby said he is having trouble pushing through the book, especially after the alien story line started. Very disappointed. I leaves you feeling cheated after the long wait.

product_title: It's Always Darkest (a Paul Mallory thriller Book 1)
review_body: My friend recommended this thriller & even lent his kindle so I could read it! Paul Mallory's offered an international reporting job by a mysterious \\\\\Mr Big\\\\\" and the fun begins. Intelligent plot & great characters - especially the leading man who it appears is a sucker for damsels in distress and has a talent for getting himself into dangerous situations. Highly recommended."
